entry.title: Please login as the user "centos" rather than the user "root".
entry.summary: Please login as the user "centos" rather than the user "root". If…
entry.content:
Please login as the user "centos" rather than the user "root".

Â 
Â 
If you tried to access your instance using SSH as root:
#Â ssh -iÂ PrivateKey.pemÂ  root@Floating-IP-AddressÂ Where Flaoting-IP-Address is the flaoting IP address associated with your instance. You might get this message: â€œPlease login as the user â€œcentosâ€ rather than the user â€œrootâ€.â€ Then the connection will close.

Steps To Allow Root Access Through SSH

  • Login as the user â€œcentosâ€: #Â ssh -iÂ PrivateKey.pemÂ  centos@Floating-IP-Address
  • Change to root: #Â sudo -s
  • Edit the file â€œ/root/.ssh/authorized_keysâ€ (#Â vi /root/.ssh/authorized_keys) and keep it only contains the keyÂ  (starts with â€œsh-rsaâ€) without the restrictions that exist at the begining of the file.
  • Open the file â€œ/etc/ssh/sshd_configâ€ and uncomment the line â€œPermitRootLogin yesâ€
  • Restart SSH daemon: #Â systemctl restart sshd
Now you can SSH as root to your instance.
Note: You need to automate the above if your servers are created/ deleted on demand and SSH public keys are inserted in servers on boot by Openstack.
